STEP 2 - EVIDENCE-BASED TREATMENT SELECTION: Now I'll select treatments based on current clinical guidelines. - First-line treatment per guidelines: Hemodynamic stabilization with IV fluids, blood transfusions if necessary, and urgent endoscopy for diagnosis and therapy. - Supporting evidence: Endoscopic intervention is the standard for bleeding peptic ulcers; IV proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) reduce rebleeding risk. - Patient-specific considerations: History of splenic vein thrombosis increases bleeding risk; anxiety may influence perception but should not delay urgent care. - Contraindications or cautions: Caution with anticoagulants if any are ongoing; monitor for volume overload during transfusions. STEP 5 - MONITORING & FOLLOW-UP STRATEGY: I'll establish appropriate monitoring and follow-up care. - Follow-up timeline: Reassess within 24-48 hours post-bleed stabilization; outpatient follow-up after discharge. - Monitoring parameters: Vital signs, hemoglobin/hematocrit, signs of rebleeding, and physical exam findings. - Red flag symptoms: Recurrent hematemesis, worsening abdominal pain, signs of shock—seek urgent care. - Treatment response assessment: Hemodynamic stability, decrease in bleeding signs, stabilization of labs.
